results.title: Lichtspiel Schwarz-Weiss-Grau
results.brief_description:
In 1930, after eight years of research and experimentation, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy created the Light Space Modulator, a kinetic sculpture of rotating glass, spirals and perforated metal sheets illuminated by 140 different light sources. In this same year, he produced the film Lightplay Black White Grey, a dynamic cinematic abstraction of the light and movement generated by the Light Space Modulator. The play of light in the film, as in the original sculpture, enabled Moholy-Nagy to create an altogether new experience for the viewer, asserting his own proposition that,
“Because light is a spatial-temporal problem, the mere accentuation of the question of light brings us into the field of a new spatial awareness that cannot yet be fully analysed. We can, however, find a word to describe it: floating.”
Moholy-Nagy also saw his Light Space Modulator as an extension of the ideas underpinning cinema - magnified light projected on a surface in dynamic configurations. As such, Lightplay Black White Grey, his cinematic mediation of these spatial and light concerns is a vital work in his artistic practise. The film begins as a series of abstract images of geometric shapes and shadows formed by the kinetic movement of the Light Space Modulator. The circular movements of the sculpture and camera in combination provide a pendulous, hypnotic effect that is both a document of the sculpture and an elegant visual dance of shape-shifting forms and transformed light. The rhythmic combinations of stasis and dynamism across altered variations of screen space and superimpositions of motion and form makes for a vertiginous visual experience.
Although it cannot replicate the immersive experience of the light sculpture, the film creates a viewing space in which the audience is visually disoriented by Moholy-Nagy’s spatial dislocations. As the artist anticipated, this creates a sensation of detachment, of ‘floating’, amid a dynamic vision of light’s relationship to spatial understanding.

results.title: Rev
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: This painterly observation of pedestrian traffic through a revolving door finds a counterpoint in the flickering of a candle flame. As separate lives are blurred with the energy of constant movement, individuals merge into an abstracted urban sound and light space.
results.description: This painterly observation of pedestrian traffic through a revolving door finds a counterpoint in the flickering of a candle flame. As separate lives are blurred with the energy of constant movement, individuals merge into an abstracted urban sound and light space.

results.title: Homosexuality: a film for discussion
results.brief_description: Designed to dispel the myths about homosexuality. Homosexuals talk about their lives, their relationships and the difficulties of growing up gay in an oppressive, intolerant society. Parents of gays speak out and the Melbourne public expresses its view on the subject.

results.title: Neat on Paper
results.creator_credit: Sydney Filmmakers' Co-op Action Group, Mandy King, James Kesteven and Miriana Marusic
results.brief_description: The Sydney Filmmakers’ Co-operative was a major national agency for the distribution and exhibition of independently produced Australian film and video for over 20 years. This program examines the issues surrounding its closure in 1986.

results.title: Boys and Balls
results.creator_credit: Gil Scrine Films, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Thermal Falls, Anna Grieve and Sue Thomson
results.brief_description: It is in games many men discover their paradise. Robert Lynd. H.G. Nelson (Greig Pickhaver) and Rampaging Roy Slaven (John Doyle) host an amusing, often hilarious exploration of the fascination of men with balls; whether it is a cricket, football, tennis, basketball, soccer, bowls, table tennis, hockey or golf ball! Celebrities including Ted Whitten, Ron Barassi, Merv Hughes, Derek Kickett, Andrew Gaze, Lindsay Gaze, Francis Awaritife, Brad Mackay, Greg Champion and the average bloke and kid next door share favourite childhood memories of their sporting idols, humerous moments, coaching temperaments, the importance of rules and umpiring, and the incidence of sporting violence. Interviews, archival footage and famous quotes are intermixed in this perceptive program.

results.title: Dispensing a cure
results.brief_description: One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region. Ian Darling and Doug McColl have each practised pharmacy for over forty years in the Warracknabeal district. In this film they recall the era when most drugs were hand-made on the premises, generally from raw materials. Ian also tells of the mysterious medicine jar labelled ‘ADT’ and of an old-fashioned coin-operated machine for a self administered electric shock.

results.title: Coromby - every Monday night
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
The Coromby Brass Band is a group of farmers who come together every Monday night to practice in a draughty hall beside the wheat silos on a back road outside the small town of Murtoa. Formed in 1891, the band is the oldest continuously active brass band in Australia. Many members have been involved for decades - in some cases, their fathers and grandfathers played in the band before them. In this film, members of the band talk about what keeps them turning up at the hall “every Monday night”.

results.title: The Finest of wheat
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
The late Don Wurfel was a farmer with an unusually keen interest in wheat breeding and the trialing of new crops for improved yields. Part of his legacy is an amazing collection of over 1500 grain varieties, most of which are housed at Wheatlands museum in Warracknabeal. In this film, Don’s son Ian talks about his father’s obsessive interest in new grain varieties and explains the importance of crop trialing for dryland farmers.

results.title: Malcolm McKinnon: 6 films for MAP at ACMI
results.brief_description: A collection of six short documentary films from an ongoing project between the filmmaker, Malcolm McKinnon, and small museums in the Wimmera farming region of Victoria. They comprise of local stories told by local people from such areas as Warracknabeal, Rainbow, Murtoa, Brim and Coromby.
results.title_for_label: Malcolm McKinnon: 6 films for MAP at ACMI

group_works.title: Disappeared racecourses of north west Victoria

results.title: Marsupial memories
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
Allan Vaughan tells the story of a funny looking stuffed kangaroo housed at the Murtoa museum. He recalls how, as a child, he used to visit the kangaroo when it was a pet belonging to his uncle. He tells how his uncle used to box with this kangaroo and also relates the story of how the animal came to end up as a taxidermic display.
